cit1.CITATION: Use of renewable resources from plant photosynthesis, garbage, and organic waste water to produce highvalue-added chemicals, materials, intermediates, and fine chemicals is now attracting growing attention and research because these resources offer advantages of renewability and biodegradability (James et al. 2011; Zhao et al. 2017).

cit2.CITATION: Use of renewable resources from plant photosynthesis, garbage, and organic waste water to produce highvalue-added chemicals, materials, intermediates, and fine chemicals is now attracting growing attention and research because these resources offer advantages of renewability and biodegradability (James et al. 2011; Zhao et al. 2017).

cit3.CITATION: Turpentine is an important renewable forest resource consisting mainly of pinene, camphene, myrcene, and small amounts of monoterpene alcohols (Li et al. 2016).

cit4.CITATION: Pinene has various functional groups such as double bonds, bridge rings, and chiral carbon groups and can therefore be hydrogenated, isomerized, oxidized, and polymerized to produce chemicals that are used as spices, medicines, pesticides, and chemical feedstocks (Liu et al. 2016; Xie et al. 2005).

cit5.CITATION: Pinene has various functional groups such as double bonds, bridge rings, and chiral carbon groups and can therefore be hydrogenated, isomerized, oxidized, and polymerized to produce chemicals that are used as spices, medicines, pesticides, and chemical feedstocks (Liu et al. 2016; Xie et al. 2005).

cit6.CITATION: In particular, hydrogenation of a-pinene to produce cis-pinane, an important intermediate that can be used for preparing linalool, dihydromyrcenol, and other terpene series species, has been attracting significant attention (Qu et al. 2018; Xie et al. 2017).

cit7.CITATION: In particular, hydrogenation of a-pinene to produce cis-pinane, an important intermediate that can be used for preparing linalool, dihydromyrcenol, and other terpene series species, has been attracting significant attention (Qu et al. 2018; Xie et al. 2017).

cit8.CITATION: Traditionally, supported metallic catalysts such as Pd/C, Pt/C, and Pt/SiO 2 have been used to catalyze hydrogenation of a-pinene to produce cis-pinane (Yang et al. 2015; Zong-liang et al. 2002).

cit9.CITATION: Traditionally, supported metallic catalysts such as Pd/C, Pt/C, and Pt/SiO 2 have been used to catalyze hydrogenation of a-pinene to produce cis-pinane (Yang et al. 2015; Zong-liang et al. 2002).

cit10.CITATION: Metal nanoparticles of Pt, Pd, Ni, Ru, and Rh offer advantages of quantum size, surface effect, volume effect, and quantum tunneling effect, showing promising application prospects in a-pinene hydrogenation (Deliy and Simakova 2008; Milewska et al. 2005; Primo et al. 2011; Wang et al. 2015; Yang et al. 2015).

cit11.CITATION: Metal nanoparticles of Pt, Pd, Ni, Ru, and Rh offer advantages of quantum size, surface effect, volume effect, and quantum tunneling effect, showing promising application prospects in a-pinene hydrogenation (Deliy and Simakova 2008; Milewska et al. 2005; Primo et al. 2011; Wang et al. 2015; Yang et al. 2015).

cit12.CITATION: Metal nanoparticles of Pt, Pd, Ni, Ru, and Rh offer advantages of quantum size, surface effect, volume effect, and quantum tunneling effect, showing promising application prospects in a-pinene hydrogenation (Deliy and Simakova 2008; Milewska et al. 2005; Primo et al. 2011; Wang et al. 2015; Yang et al. 2015).

cit13.CITATION: Metal nanoparticles of Pt, Pd, Ni, Ru, and Rh offer advantages of quantum size, surface effect, volume effect, and quantum tunneling effect, showing promising application prospects in a-pinene hydrogenation (Deliy and Simakova 2008; Milewska et al. 2005; Primo et al. 2011; Wang et al. 2015; Yang et al. 2015).

cit14.CITATION: Metal nanoparticles of Pt, Pd, Ni, Ru, and Rh offer advantages of quantum size, surface effect, volume effect, and quantum tunneling effect, showing promising application prospects in a-pinene hydrogenation (Deliy and Simakova 2008; Milewska et al. 2005; Primo et al. 2011; Wang et al. 2015; Yang et al. 2015).

cit15.CITATION: However, Ru nanoparticles will aggregate because of their high surface energy, resulting in a low conversion of a-pinene (Qu et al. 2018; Rauchdi et al. 2017).

cit16.CITATION: However, Ru nanoparticles will aggregate because of their high surface energy, resulting in a low conversion of a-pinene (Qu et al. 2018; Rauchdi et al. 2017).

cit17.CITATION: Therefore, stabilizers must be added to achieve controlled nanoparticle morphology, stability, and dispersion (Cao et al. 2010).

cit18.CITATION: The use of polymers such as polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA), and polyacrylamide (PAM) is a promising approach to stabilize nanoparticles because surfactants are easy to obtain and in most cases very economical (Capek 2004; Kiran et al. 2010; Nehru et al. 2017; Yan et al. 2011).
